entry.title: Re: Together with property 'ScheduleLineOrderQuantity' al...
entry.content:
Hello @Rawel 

It's not the POST path that's causing the error, but rather the payload itself. Two key points to note:

Date format â€“ use OData V4 ISO-8601 ("2025-10-08T00:00:00Z") instead of "/Date(...)/".

Quantity with unit â€“ always send PurchaseOrderQuantityUnit with the schedule line quantity.

Deep insert operates directly through /PurchaseOrder with nested items and schedule lines. The â€œSchedule Lineâ€ path is unnecessary unless updating an existing PO.

Also check:

PC is valid for the material

remove SupplyingPlant unless itâ€™s an STO

donâ€™t send empty custom fields

For more detail check you inbox

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Business Partner replication to EWM â€“ General Role (0...
entry.content:
To answer your first question, No, not in Public Cloud. In the Public Edition, the â€œGeneralâ€ BP role (000000) is a technical role that exists in the backend but is not exposed in the Maintain Business Partner app, nor in any released API or DRF configuration.

To your second question, yes, you can go with this approach. Implement BAdI /SCWM/EX_BP_INBOUND in decentralized EWM. Check if role 000000 is missing in the inbound payload, in your implementation. If missing, add it before the BP is created/updated in EWM.

Best practice is to keep the S/4 side standard and handle the requirement in EWM, and monitor it.

entry.title: Re: Subtotals on Adobe Forms
entry.content:
Thanks for the blog!

I used the idea with the subtotal flag for my form.
One suggestion from my side:
If you read the subtotal flag not from the subform, you don't even need to add the field to the layout (and to hide it later).

In my case it looks like that:

 var rowCount = this._DATA.count;
 
 for (var i = 0; i < rowCount; i++) {  
   var objNameSubtotal = "$record.GT_ANNEX.DATA[" + i + "].SUBTOTAL_LINE";          
   var subtotalNode = xfa.resolveNode(objNameSubtotal);
    
   if (subtotalNode.value == 'X' ) {
     // Do something
   }
}

entry.title: Re: Is it safe to switch from "Standard ABAP" to "ABAP fo...
entry.content:
Without going to S/4HANA Public Cloud yet, if one program needs no modification, is it safe to not test it and keep the ABAP Language Version "ABAP for Cloud Development" in S/4HANA on premises?

No, it's not safe. For instance, you would get the runtime error CALL_METHOD_NOT_PERMITTED raised when calling GET_DDIC_FIELD of CL_ABAP_ELEMDESCR and few other methods (source: Public Cloud Alternative for FM DDIF_FIELDINFO_GET... - SAP Community), even if it runs in S/4HANA on premises (the kernel tests the ABAP Language Version of the class).

entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam introduces attendees to service integration with the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). Specifically, the Node.js flavor of CAP is used.

During this event, you'll become acquainted with how external services can be integrated and consumed from within a CAP project. In working through the exercises you'll also become comfortable with various facilities that CDS offers for declaring, relating and exposing entities, and familiar with how the SAP Cloud SDK covers connectivity and destinations, supporting such integration scenarios with CAP.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Fri 10 Oct 2025 in Munich, DE. It is being kindly hosted at SAP Labs Munich, in Garching. It takes place the day before SAP Inside Track Munich which is also at the same location on Sat 11 Oct.

The instructor is Developer Advocate DJ Adams. 

There are essential prerequisites that must be completed by every attendee, before arriving at the event location. They are documented here: https://github.com/SAP-samples/cap-service-integration-codejam/blob/main/prerequisites.md.

If you wish to attend, please indicate that using the "I'm attending" facility on this page. Please note that spaces are limited - we can only accommodate 24 attendees for this event. In that context, if you indicate that you're attending and later realise you can't, please remove your name so that others get a chance instead. Thanks!

For more information on SAP CodeJam events, to ask questions, and to chat with your fellow attendees, head over to the SAP CodeJam group.

Issue Summary

In the Automatic Payment Program (F110), when offsetting a foreign currency vendor invoice (debit/black line item) against a credit memo (credit/red line item) for the same vendor with exactly the same amount, it is expected that the payment proposal will net to zero and no payment will be generated. However, in the payment proposal, the items are split and treated as separate payments.

Detailed Conditions

  • Transaction: F110 (Automatic Payment Program)

  • Currency: SGD (the same behavior occurs with other foreign currencies as well)

  • Document conditions:

    • Invoice (debit/black): 100 SGD

    • Credit memo (credit/red): â€“100 SGD

    • Payment method, house bank, company code, and payment currency are identical between the two documents

  • Behavior in local currency (JPY):

    • In similar cases in JPY, the payment proposal correctly nets the items together, resulting in a zero payment which can be processed without splitting

Actual Result

  • Only in the case of foreign currency, the payment proposal splits the items into separate payments

  • In the proposal log, the flag REGUE-POKEN (item-level payment indicator) is set, causing the items to be treated as individual payments

Expected Behavior

  • Even for foreign currency, when the invoice and the credit memo net to zero, the items should be grouped together in the payment proposal and no payment should be generated

  • The behavior should be consistent with local currency (JPY)

Additional Notes

  • All document conditions (payment method, house bank, currency, etc.) are confirmed to be identical

  • In local currency (JPY), zero payments are handled correctly

  • The POKEN flag is only set in foreign currency cases, which seems to be the root cause, but it is unclear why this happens only for foreign currencies

entry.title: How to Log Client IP Addresses Correctly in SAP CDC Audit Logs
entry.content:
Hi, we are facing an issue where we are expecting the Client app IP address to be logged correctly in the Audit logs. Instead of logging the client IP address, it is currently logging the Content Delivery Network (CDN) (for example: Cloudflare) IP address, which is not desired. Somehow, we are losing the client IP.
Please guide us to resolve this issue, "how to log client mobile App IP correctly in CDC?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to Log Client IP Addresses Correctly in SAP CDC A...
entry.content:
Why is it not logging client IP in CDC Audit logs?

  • When using a Content Delivery Network (CDN) like Cloudflare, the IP address captured by CDC is the IP address of the CDN server that forwarded the request, not the client's IP address. This is because the request is proxied through the CDN, which masks the client's original IP address.

How can we log client IP correctly in CDC Audit Logs?

  • To log the client's IP address correctly in CDC audit logs, you can include a custom header named "X-Gigya-Client-IP" in your API requests to CDC.
  • Here's an example of how to add this header using our PHP SDK: Auditing User's IP Address from REST Calls.

By including the "X-Gigya-Client-IP" header in API requests, you should be able to log the client's IP address correctly in CDC audit logs. You then see this value available in the audit.search endpoint under "httpReq.Headers".

entry.title: Re: how to take return for damaged SFG and RM material ba...
entry.content: Advanced Returns Management with Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge (SDF) will meet your requirement, in Public Cloud. Of course, in return order, you need to enter manually the damaged part, assign the original order as a reference document. Set the Refund Type to Replacement material. Once you create a return delivery, the respective stock will get posted in QI, depending upon your config. Enter the replacement material in the return order under "Returns" tab, so that, system will trigger SDF document. With this approach, your customer will receive only a replacement material for the damaged one.

entry.title: DP Agent Configuration With BTP Hana Cloud Instance
entry.content:
Hello Folks,

Recently, I faced some challenges while configuring the Data Provisioning (DP) Agent with an SAP HANA Cloud instance. In this blog, I want to highlight some important prerequisites, tips, and configuration steps that helped me resolve the issues. I hope this helps others going through the same process.

Before jumping into the configuration, ensure the following network prechecks are done properly:

1. Inbound IP Allowlist from the DP Agent Server

From your DP Agent host machine, make sure inbound IPs are allowed according to the BTP region where your HANA Cloud instance resides as per this guide BTP subaccount region network IP

Example: In my trial account, I allowed all TCP inbound IPs via the VMâ€™s security group (see screenshot below).
However, for production environments, itâ€™s recommended to allow only the specific subnet range based on your BTP subaccount region for better security.

2. IP Allowlist and DP Agent Enabled on HANA Cloud

On the SAP HANA Cloud instance side:

Ensure that IP allowlisting is properly configured to accept connections from your DP Agent server.

Also, enable DP Agent connectivity in the SAP HANA Cloud cockpit.

Iâ€™ve attached screenshots showing these settings from my trial setup.

 

After completing these two network-level checks, you can verify connectivity using the telnet command to the HANA Cloud host and port. If that works, you're good to proceed with the agent configuration.

Now In terms of connectivity we are ready for the configuration.

configuration :

Before starting the actual configuration, make sure you have the following users ready.

1. Agent Admin HANA User - Generally DBADMIN User

2. HANA User Name for Agent Messaging - Technical user as per your requirements, refer to SAP help guide for user creation, roles, and privileges.

Users, Roles, and Privileges 

3. Most important

This step is often overlooked and causes issues during JDBC-based connectivity.

Make sure to update the following parameters in your dpagentconfig.ini file:

jdbc.enabled=true
jdbc.encrypt=true

If these are not set correctly, you may encounter JDBC errors while connecting to any BTP service.

These settings are mandatory for encrypted JDBC communication.

Once everything is in place, run the agentcli tool to configure your DP Agent.

Now you are able to register the agent in your SAP HANA Cloud instance

you can also verify the result from hana cloud instance.

If you're planning to set up data replication, I highly recommend checking out this excellent blog by haruki blog

 

I hope this post helps others avoid the common pitfalls I encountered.

Thanks for reading! Feel free to drop comments or questions â€” Iâ€™d be happy to help

entry.title: Re: PRICAT in SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Retail
entry.content:
PRICAT are not released for customer use, in Public Edition. Public Cloud uses released APIs and the Retailâ€‘specific EDI message types are not part of the released scope. If there is a need to exchange price catalogue data in Public Cloud, you must use the released APIs for product and condition replication, or an integration via SAP Integration Suite that transforms to/from PRICAT on the partner side.

For Private Cloud, yes, you can use PRICAT IDocs exactly as in onâ€‘premise. You can configure ALE/EDI, partner profiles, and process PRICAT inbound/outbound. This is the route if you want to keep existing PRICATâ€‘based integrations with minimal change.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud RF Application customization usi...
entry.content:
Hello @PhaniDeepthi_Akula 

Thank you for your question.

Please note that the RF Framework is a standard solution delivered in the Public Cloud. Therefore, it cannot be modified with enhancements like you have in an on-premise solution. The classic RF screens are locked down in public cloud to ensure upgrades are easily installed and compatible.

To achieve your requirement to create a custom button â€œGR + Label Printâ€ with navigation to a custom UI flow, the recommended approach in public cloud is:

  • For your inbound processing and label printing, make use of the Fiori Apps that are available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  • If the standard apps do not cover the exact scenario, consider building a custom Fiori App via the SAP BTP extension (In-App Extensibility)  and integrate the app into your RF menu. side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP. This will enable your users to select the desired â€œGR + Label Printâ€ option ensuring they are redirected to your custom Fiori Flow.

To validate the value entered on the custom screen, the validation logic must be implemented in the custom Fiori app backend service using OData/Rest service which are published in S/4HANA Public Cloud. Please note that your input checks are validated against the Cloud APIs or CDS view.

Consult the following links for more details.

RF Framework

How to use RF scanner in the EWM S/4HANA Cloud system?

side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP.

In-App Extensibility

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Story report for concurrent employment
entry.content:

entry.title: Re: Error in BAPI_CONDITION_CONTRACT_CHANGE No data is ch...
entry.content:
It seems, you have not set the change indicator flag correctly. For any field you want to change, you must fill the value in CONDITIONITEMDATAIN, Set the corresponding field in CONDITIONITEMDATAINX to 'X' or the correct change indicator. Also set UPDATEFLAG = 'U' in CONDITIONITEMDATAINX for that condition line. If you donâ€™t set the X flags, the BAPI ignores the field even if you pass a new value.

From buffering issue point of view, if you check WCOCO immediately after the BAPI in the same LUW/session, you might still see buffered old data. Exit and reâ€‘enter the transaction to confirm.

entry.title: CREATING CAPM APPLICATION WITH NODE.JS BY USING S/4 HANA DATABASE
entry.content:
Hello All,

In this Blog I would like to share some knowledge on how to Create a basic CAPM application using Sap Business Application Studio and we are going to use the SAP S/4 Hana system to connect and fetch the data.

Lets Divide this Blog into three sections:

1. Prerequisites

2.  Connecting with S/4 HANA Data Base.

3.CRUD Operations

In this Blog lets see what are all the subscriptions and settings to be done to start our application.

Let.. Set.. Go!!

NOTE: May Be This Blog Seems To Be Lengthy, Still Give It A Try U Will Surely Love IT ğŸ˜€

 

 

 

Step1: Lets Subscribe to SAP HANA CLOUD:

Open your SAP BTP trial account and navigate to Service Market Place. Search for S/4 Hana Cloud

 

After Selecting HANA Cloud, you will get the screen like below and Please click on Create.  

 

 

 

Click on Tools and then Create.

 

Once you click on View Subscription , here it shows as below image

 

Note: Remember after subscribing any service you should add security because every service will have its own Role Collections.

Now lets navigate to Users and Click on Default Identity Provider.

 

 

Click on Assign Role Collections, there you can find roles related to Hana cloud( You will find all the roles for the services that are subscribed).

 

 

Select them and click and assign.

 

You can find them under your role collections. Now you have your HANA DB. Lets open it.

 

Step2: Open SAP HANA Cloud and Lets Create Instance.

 

Click on Create Instance and then select HANA Cloud DB.

 

 

 

Here its asking us from which environment our service is going to run, So we need to sign in to Cloud Foundry with your Default Identity Provider Credentials( your email id).Then it returns you this Message.

 

 

 

 

 

Select your space which is default given as dev ( I renamed its as Dev). Instance name can be anything of your choice.

 

 

Enter any password of your choice.

Now leave the next step as it is with storage of 16gb and next please select allow all IP addresses so that it will not block any.

 

 

Click on the three dots over there and there you will find an option to Start. In 10 to 15min your instance would be running.

 

 

Step 3: Setup Work Zone(Fiori Launch Pad):

Search in Market Place > Work Zone

 

Click Create 

 

Please select the Plan as Subscriptions > standard. 

 

Our Subscription would be in progress.

 

 

Note: If this error exists, please subscribe to your Cloud Identity Services.

If you get this, please add trust configuration. So follow the steps below

Initially follow the same process of Subscribing Cloud Identity Provider User Role Collections

Fix: Configure OIDC Trust in SAP BTP

  1. Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit
    Go to your subaccount where you want to subscribe to the application.
  2. Go to Security â†’ Trust Configuration
    This is where you manage identity provider (IdP) trust settings.
  3. Add SAP Cloud Identity Services as an OIDC IdP
    • Click Establish Trust.
    • Choose SAP Cloud Identity Services.
    • Select OpenID Connect (not SAML).
    • Enter the required details (Issuer URL, Client ID, etc.) â€” if you have Identity Authentication service (IAS) set up, you can copy these from there.
  4. Set as Default for Business Users

                  ï‚· Make sure the new OIDC IdP is assigned to business users in your subaccount.

  1. Save & Retry Subscription
    Go back to the subscription page and try again.

Assign the Role collections to users what are all available. Check them all and Click on Assign.

Step 4: CREATE A HANA DB INSTANCE:

Navigate to Service Market Place > Select HANA DB > Create > Under Plan select the Instance.

 

Step 5: Subscribe to Business Application Studio.

Note: By default SAP Business Application Studio would be subscribed. If not subscribe it by yourself.

 

Are you all done!! Lets get into next Episode soon...

References:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/

https://help.sap.com/fiori_bs2013/helpdata/en/a7/1564526ba1f25fe10000000a423f68/content.htm?no_cache...

Hope itâ€™s helpful ğŸ˜‰

 

Thanks,
Divya MANDAVA.

entry.title: Re: Accelerate the depreciation of one asset
entry.content:
Hello @Dylan2 

Thank you for reaching out to the SAP Community. Your question and the shared screenshot are very helpful

What you have done with transaction type 640 â€“ Unplanned Depreciation on prior-year acquisitions is technically correct, but it explains why you donâ€™t see the 500 CNY as accelerated depreciation under ledger 0L in Manage Fixed Assets.

Why:

Transaction type 640 is used for impairments or extraordinary write-downs. It generates an FI posting and appears in the Transactions / Asset History Sheet view, but it does not modify planned depreciation.

Only the values calculated from the depreciation key and useful life are considered by the depreciation engine. Manual postings made with 640 are not included in the depreciation forecast.

If the goal is to accelerate future depreciation:

Use the Change Asset Master Data app.

Reduce the useful life or alter the depreciation key in the Time-Dependent Data section.

Once the system has recalculated the planned depreciation, youâ€™ll see the changes reflected under ledger 0L in Manage Fixed Assets.

When should you use 640?

Only for true unplanned depreciation events such as impairments, damage, or extraordinary value reductions

SAP Help Portal â€“ Depreciation Posting Run

Post Depreciation Manually - Unplanned and Planned

SAP Help Portal â€“ Change Asset Master Data

In brief, the method you used posts correctly, but it doesnâ€™t speed up planned depreciation. To do that, you need to update the master data (useful life or key) so that the system recalculates depreciation in future runs.

Feel free to reach out again if you still need further support

Thanks again, and kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Data Replication Framework - BusinessPartner Replicat...
entry.content:
Hello @StevenKr 

Thank you for the question.

Note that when you try to replicate BP master data to SAP EWM using the SAP_COM_0008 communication scenario in SAP Public Cloud, the general BP Role is always required. Without it, EWM cannot interpret the Customer or the supplier roles. These depend on the General role as a foundation to that process.

If EWM receives either Customer or Supplier role but not the General role, the replication will fail with the error as it does in your scenario.

I recommend you evaluate the following checks:

  • Confirm that the BP indeed has the 000000-General BP Role assigned.  KBA 3059674 Which is required by EWM to be sent along with the Customer/Supplier roles.
  • Check the replication model setup and ensure the Define Business Partner configuration does not have any role exclusion.
  • You mentioned that your EWM colleague sees only FLCU01/FLVN0, that means the general role was not transmitted or processed. Review the payload sent via the SOAP service using the Message Dashboard to verify the General Role 000000 is included. If this is present and it still does not arrive in EWM, then issue is on the EWM configuration.
  • You should ensure that you create all BPs with General Role. Thereafter re-run replications for all affected BPs.

If after taking those steps the issue still persists then raise an incident under LO-MD-BP which represents the Business Partner and make a reference to SAP_COM_0008 scenario.

Consult the following for more details.

KBA 3245240 Filters for Business Partner (SAP_COM_0008) SOAP Replication Not Taking Effect

KBA 3329385

KBA 3059674

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Which technologies are used to develop travel apps?
entry.content:
Great question! Travel apps require a mix of frontend, backend, mobile frameworks, APIs, and cloud technologies to deliver smooth, scalable, and feature-rich experiences for users. Hereâ€™s a breakdown of the main technologies used to develop travel apps:

1. Frontend Development (User Interface)

This is what users see and interact with:

  • Mobile Frameworks:

    • Swift / Objective-C â†’ iOS native apps

    • Java / Kotlin â†’ Android native apps

    • Flutter (Dart) â†’ Cross-platform (single codebase for iOS & Android)

    • React Native (JavaScript) â†’ Cross-platform development

  • UI Libraries & Tools: Material UI (Android), SwiftUI (iOS), Shadcn/UI, Tailwind CSS

2. Backend Development (Server-Side & Logic)

Handles data processing, booking logic, and secure transactions:

  • Programming Languages:

    • Python (Django, Flask, FastAPI)

    • Node.js (Express.js, NestJS)

    • Java (Spring Boot)

    • PHP (Laravel, Symfony)

    • Ruby on Rails

  • Databases:

    • Relational: PostgreSQL, MySQL

    • NoSQL: MongoDB, Firebase Realtime DB

3. APIs & Integrations (Core for Travel Apps)

Travel apps rely heavily on third-party integrations:

  • Flight & Hotel APIs: Amadeus, Skyscanner, Expedia, Booking.com, Sabre, Travelport

  • Maps & Location: Google Maps, Mapbox, OpenStreetMap

  • Weather APIs: OpenWeatherMap, Weatherstack

  • Payment Gateways: Stripe, PayPal, Razorpay, Braintree

  • Chat & Support: Twilio, Sendbird, Firebase Messaging

4. Cloud & Hosting Services

For scalability and performance:

  • AWS (Amazon Web Services) â†’ EC2, S3, RDS, Lambda

  • Google Cloud Platform (GCP) â†’ Firebase, BigQuery

  • Microsoft Azure â†’ App Services, SQL Database

  • Heroku / DigitalOcean for startups & MVPs

5. Security & Compliance

Since travel apps handle payments and personal data:

  • Authentication: OAuth 2.0, JWT, Firebase Auth

  • Encryption: SSL/TLS, AES-256

  • Compliance: GDPR (Europe), PCI DSS (Payments), CCPA (California)

6. AI & Smart Features

For personalization and user experience:

  • Chatbots / Virtual Assistants â†’ Dialogflow, IBM Watson, Rasa

  • AI Recommendations â†’ TensorFlow, PyTorch, ML Kit

  • Language Translation â†’ Google Translate API, Microsoft Translator

7. Other Essential Tools

  • Analytics: Google Analytics, Firebase Analytics, Mixpanel

  • Push Notifications: Firebase Cloud Messaging, OneSignal

  • Testing: Appium, Selenium, XCTest, JUnit

  • CI/CD: GitHub Actions, Jenkins, Bitrise

âœ… In short:

  • Native apps â†’ Swift (iOS), Kotlin (Android)

  • Cross-platform apps â†’ Flutter, React Native

  • Backend â†’ Node.js, Python, or Java

  • Cloud â†’ AWS, GCP, Azure

  • APIs â†’ Travel booking, payment, maps, weather integrations

entry.title: Re: How to connect from SAP Public cloud(Odata) to SAP ME...
entry.content:
Hello @Sah1 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, you can connect the Public Cloud via OData APIs to an external MES system such as the ones (which can include a third-party solution) you mentioned in your question. However, there are some differences if you compare that to the classic on-prem RFC/JCO connections.

Please note that in SAP Public Cloud, direct RFC calls are not supported. Instead, all integration must go through the public APIs which are available in the SAP API Business Hub.

To answer your question on integration options for MES, make sure you use OData APIs from the S/4HANA cloud. Third Party MES Integration With SAP S4HANA Cloud, SAP Digital Manufacturing Integration Guide Connect your MES systems either through:

  • HTTPs calls to the S/4HANA Cloud OData endpoints or
  • Through SAP CPI as a middleware, which is the recommended approach to handle authentication, mappings and error handling.

Please note that you must create a Communication User + Communication Arrangement for the required OData API. Third Party MES Integration With SAP S4HANA Cloud

To consume MES, configure REST/OData clinets. SAP MII as an example can call OData endpoints directly via HTTP adapter and not through JCO.

Consult the references below for more details.

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Third Party MES Integration With SAP S4HANA Cloud

Integrating Plant Data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to SAP Integrated Business Planning

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S4 tables for Invoice Lifecycle Report?
entry.content:
The OBJECTID in CDHDR/CDPOS is for the changeâ€‘document object like BKPF for FI header, RBKP for MM invoice header. So unless the field youâ€™re looking for is part of that objectâ€™s changeâ€‘doc definition, it wonâ€™t be logged there.

Depending on whether you are using standard S/4HANA AP workflow or OpenText VIM, the relevant tables differ:

Below are the Standard S/4HANA Invoice Workflow

  • SWWWIHEAD â€“ Workflow item header (task, work item ID, current agent)
  • SWWUSERWI â€“ Work item â†’ user assignment
  • SWWLOGHIST â€“ Workflow log history (status changes)
  • SWW_CONT / SWW_CONTOB â€“ Container elements (process type, document refs)

Similarly, for MM/FI header, you can consider, RBKP which will link to workflow via object key and BKPF.

Now in order to join to your document ID, start from your invoice number in RBKP (for MM) or BKPF (for FI). Get the workflow instance ID from the linkage table (SWWORGTASK or via event linkage in SWEINST). Join to SWWWIHEAD / SWWUSERWI to get the current agent. Join to SWWLOGHIST to get the history rows you see in the Life Cycle report.

entry.title: API & Excipient Calculation in Process Order by MQC
entry.content:
Hi SAP Folks,

Need your help in the following client requirement.

Requirement: 

Client is manufacturing 5 lakh Nos. tablets:

1. Components are API & Excipient.

2. Both the components are stock-up in batches.

3. API component is having Assay & LOD characteristics.

4. Quantity of API is calculated using the following formula,

    = (400 X 100 X 100)/((100 - LOD) X Assay)

& Quantity of Excipient is calculated using the following formula,

   = 205 - Quantity of API

5. Every Batch of API will have different Assay and LOD values (LOD = 0 - 0.5%, Assay = 98 - 100%)

Example - 

Batch A --> LOD = 0.3% & Assay = 99.60%

Quantity of API = (400 X 100 X 100)/((100 - 0.3) X 99.60) = 402.815 mg/tab

Quantity of API required for manufacturing 5 L tabs = (402.815 X 5 L)/(1000 X 1000) = 201.407 kg

But already there is a batch, Batch E of 180 kg quantity.

So, how many tablets could be produced using Batch E = 180 kg quantity of API,

= (180 X 1000 X 1000)/(402.815) = 4,46,855 Nos of tablets

No. of tablets to be produce from Batch B = 500000 - 446855 = 53,145 Nos.

Batch B --> Assay = 99.90% & LOD = 0.5%

Quantity of API = (400 X 100 X 100)/((100 - 0.5) X 99.90) = 402.412 mg/tab

Qty. required for 53,145 tabs = (53145 X 402.412)/(1000 X 1000) = 21.386 kg

Actual Qty of API - 180 + 21.386 =  201.386 kg

Excipient qty = 205 - 201.386 = 3.614 kg

 

Thanks & Regards 

#Material Quantity Calculation  SAP Industry Process Framework SAP Help Portal SAP Community SAP S/4HANA SAP ERP

entry.title: Innovating with SAP C4C: Dynamic MDRO to Handle Massive Ticket Updates
entry.content:
Disclaimer:

  • This blog does not cover the basics of creating an MDRO.
  • The business logic described here is for illustration purposes only and cannot include actual production details due to organizational policies.

Introduction

In SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), Mass Data Run Objects (MDROs) are commonly used to execute bulk updates in the background. They act like scheduled jobs where you define selection filters, write custom code, and let the system process records in batches.

But when working with millions of records in SAP Service Cloud, standard MDROs quickly run into performance bottlenecks â€” primarily the 10-hour runtime limit.

In this blog, Iâ€™ll explain how we solved this limitation by designing an innovative Dynamic MDRO framework that can handle tens of millions of tickets seamlessly.

Use Case

Product: SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C)
Objective: Update Service Tickets using MDRO
Scenario: A new Quarter field was introduced on tickets, and we needed to populate it based on ticket creation month:

Month Quarter
Jan â€“ MarQ1
Apr â€“ JunQ2
Jul â€“ SepQ3
Oct â€“ DecQ4

(Actual business logic was more complex and involved massive datasets. This is a simplified illustration.)

The Challenge with Standard MDRO

When we tried updating ~40 million tickets using a single MDRO, we hit a critical issue:

SAP C4C MDROs fail when a package execution exceeds 10 hours.

SAPâ€™s Recommendation:

  • Reduce the selection data volume

  • Break the updates into multiple scheduled runs

Our Constraint:
We couldnâ€™t reduce the dataset â€” every ticket needed to be updated in one logical flow.

Our Solution: Dynamic MDRO (Nested MDRO Approach)

To overcome these limitations, we designed a Dynamic MDRO framework:

  1. Parent MDRO â†’ Fetches eligible records in configurable intervals (e.g., creation dates).

  2. Data Chunking â†’ Splits large datasets into smaller batches automatically.

  3. Child MDROs â†’ For each batch, a new child MDRO is created dynamically and executed.

  4. Parameterization â†’ Batch size is configurable (default 500 records per MDRO).

How It Works

  • Step 1: Parent MDRO identifies the full dataset.

  • Step 2: It divides the dataset into smaller logical packages.

  • Step 3: It triggers multiple child MDROs dynamically, each handling a small subset.

  • Step 4: Since each MDRO deals with fewer records, execution time stays well below the 10-hour limit.

Key Features

  • âš¡Parameterized Batching â†’ Fully configurable batch size

  • ğŸ¤–Automated Execution â†’ No manual intervention needed

  • ğŸ“ˆHigh Scalability â†’ Works seamlessly with tens of millions of records

  • âœ…Timeout-Free â†’ Each MDRO stays well within SAP limits

ğŸš€Groundbreaking Performance Improvement 

Before implementing Dynamic MDRO, we were stuck with:

  • ~7,000 tickets processed in 10 hours using standard MDRO

  • At this pace, updating 40M+ tickets would have taken months or even years

After implementing Dynamic MDRO:

  • We updated millions of tickets in just ~20 minutes 

  • Achieved end-to-end automation without manual intervention

  • Delivered one of the fastest, most optimized solutions in our SAP Service Cloud landscape

This was a game-changing result that completely redefined how we handle mass updates in SAP C4C.

Benefits Achieved

Aspect Standard MDRO Dynamic MDRO (Our Approach)
Data VolumeLimitedUnlimited
Timeout Handling10-hour riskEliminated
AutomationPartialFully automated
PerformanceSlower with large dataHighly optimized

Groundbreaking Performance Improvement ğŸš€

Before implementing Dynamic MDRO, we were stuck with:

  • ~7,000 tickets processed in 10 hours using standard MDRO

  • At this pace, updating 40M+ tickets would have taken months or even years

After implementing Dynamic MDRO:

  • We updated millions of tickets in just ~20 minutes 

  • Achieved end-to-end automation without manual intervention

  • Delivered one of the fastest, most optimized solutions in our SAP Service Cloud landscape

This was a game-changing result that completely redefined how we handle mass updates in SAP C4C.

Conclusion

By designing a Dynamic MDRO in SAP C4C, we:

  • Solved the 10-hour runtime limitation

  • Automated mass updates for ~40M tickets

  • Built a scalable, reusable framework

This approach can be applied wherever standard MDROs fail due to data volume constraints.

Final Note

âš ï¸Disclaimer: The logic used here is for illustration only and cannot reflect the actual production logic due to confidentiality.


Next Blog Preview

In my next blog, Iâ€™ll cover:

  • How to create child MDRO from Parent MDRO

  • Technical details from SDK

entry.title: Re: TDS provisioning
entry.content:
In your original provision (Enter provisions â€“ India), the system calculated exactly â‚¹6â€¯000 (10% of â‚¹60â€¯000) based on the SES amount and the WHT code. When you later post the supplier invoice, the WHT engine recalculates the tax amount from the invoice line(s). If thereâ€™s any difference in base amount (e.g. due to currency conversion, unit price rounding, or inclusion/exclusion of freight/other conditions), the calculated WHT can differ by a few paise.

For information, the Utilise provisions â€“ India app doesnâ€™t just â€œpick upâ€ the original â‚¹6â€¯000 â€” it matches the open WHT line items from the invoice to the provision and posts the utilisation for the actual open amount. If the invoice WHT line is â‚¹6â€¯000.50, the posting will round to â‚¹6â€¯001 in the G/L. This is why you see Withholding Tax A/C Dr 6â€¯001 / To TDS Provision A/C 6â€¯001.

In order to confirm this, display the FI document for the supplier invoice (FB03) and check the exact WHT line item amount in document currency and local currency. Youâ€™ll likely see itâ€™s not exactly â‚¹6â€¯000.00.

Now coming to "Not Assigned" issue, in the Post with Clearing screen of the Create Remittance Challan app, the â€œAssignedâ€ total must match the sum of the open WHT items you want to remit. In your case, you have two open items on the WHT account:

  • â‚¹6â€¯001 from the invoice (paymentâ€‘time WHT)
  • â‚¹6â€¯001 from the provision utilisation

If you only select one of them, the other remains â€œNot assignedâ€, and the â€œNot assignedâ€ column will show the combined total of the unassigned items (â‚¹12â€¯002 if both are unassigned). The challan process expects you to select all relevant open WHT items for that section code/TAN and assign them to the payment line.

In order to fix this, in the selection screen, make sure you filter by the correct section code and TAN so both items appear. In the line item list, select both â‚¹6â€¯001 items and assign them to the bank clearing line. The â€œNot assignedâ€ amount should drop to zero before you post.

entry.title: Re: TDS provisioning
entry.content:
Hello @Rishav4 

Your detailed scenario is correct for e2e TDS provision handling in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud focusing on India localisation.

Looking at the first issue in step 4 about 6001 instead of 6000, this is a rounding difference. The reason is

  • in Public Cloud, withholding tax calculation is always aligned with invoice-base WHT determination and your system currency setting.
  • Decimals are rounded differently, especially when tax base or percentages are calculated across multiple line items during provision creation and further utilisation. That explains why the system rounded the extra â‚¹1.

The second issue you mentioned about the error you experience in Remittance Challan usually occurs for some reasons.

  1. Your provision document is already utilised and reserved but the corresponding tax payable balance is not available in the WHT account.
  2. There is a mismatch in the challan grouping due to the extra rounding.
  3. The challan app requires the correct balance in the WHT payable account to match the provisioned amounts.

I recommend you check:

First, in the App â€œDisplay Line Items in General Ledgerâ€ to ensure that the WHT payable account has the correct balance (6000 vs. 6001)

Then, in the Manage Journal Entries Fiori app, trace the provision and check if the extra rounding line is sitting unallocated.

Finally, if you find a mismatch, run the Utilize Provisions-Indiaâ€ again or post a small manual adjustment journal entry to align the balances before you generate the challan.

If the mismatch persists, consider opening an SAP incident under component FI-LOC-FI-IN

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris
